questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with symptoms of a respiratory infection. A sputum sample is taken and cultured. The isolated organism shows pink, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. Biochemical tests are performed, and the organism is found to be urease-positive, indole-negative, and citrate-positive. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Klebsiella pneumoniae Explanation: The following tests are used to identify Klebsiella pneumoniae MacConkey Agar: Pink, mucoid colonies indicate lactose fermentation and a capsule-producing bacterium, both characteristic of Klebsiella pneumoniae. Urease-positive: Klebsiella pneumoniae produces urease, which breaks down urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide. Indole-negative: Klebsiella pneumoniae does not produce indole from tryptophan, differentiating it from Escherichia coli, which is indole-positive. Citrate-positive: Klebsiella pneumoniae can utilize citrate as its sole carbon source. Laboratory diagnosis of Klebsiella pneumoniae: Gram staining: It is short, plump, straight capsulated gram-negative rods Culture: On MacConkey agar, it produces large dome-shaped mucoid (due to capsule) sticky, pink color, lactose fermenting colonies. Klebsiella " data-author="Ajay Kumar Chaurasiya" data-hash="10230" data-license="CC BY SA 4.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Klebsiella_pneumoniae_mucoid_lactose_fer menter_%28MLF%29_colonies_on_MacConkey_agar.jpg" data-tags="April2025" height="337" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/013JgD6IquYKKk9lrSKK1744499266.jpeg" width="450" /> Identification: Identification of K. pneumoniae from colonies is made either by automated identification systems such as MALDI-TOF or VITEK; or by conventional biochemical tests as described below It is catalase positive and oxidase negative ICUT tests: Indole test (negative), citrate test (positive), urease test (positive) and TSI (triple sugar iron agar) test shows acid/acid, gas present, H2S absent. Escherichia coli (Option A): Although it can appear pink on MacConkey agar due to lactose fermentation, E. coli is indole-positive and urease-negative, ruling it out. Proteus mirabilis (Option C): Proteus species are typically non-lactose fermenting and would not appear pink on MacConkey agar. They also do not appear mucoid. Enterobacter cloacae (Option D): While this organism is citrate-positive and a lactose fermenter, it generally lacks the mucoid, highly capsulated appearance of Klebsiella pneumoniae colonies and is urease-negative.

questions.question: A microbiologist observes samples of bacteria and notes that the bacteria exhibit motility at 22°C but become non-motile at 37 °C. Additionally, the bacteria is better isolated when kept at 4°C, and weekly subcultures are done. Which of the following organisms is least likely to be in the sample?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Yersinia pestis Explanation: Differential motility refers to the ability of bacteria to be motile at lower temperatures (22°C) and non-motile at higher temperatures (37°C). Cold enrichment refers to the process of enhanced isolation of certain bacteria at lower temperatures (4°C) where other bacteria fail to grow. Organism Differential Motility (22°C vs 37°C) Cold Enrichment Isolation Yersinia enterocolitica (Option A) Motile at 22°C, Non-motile at 37°C Yes Yersinia pseudotuberculosis (Option B) Motile at 22°C, Non-motile at 37°C Yes Listeria monocytogens (Option C) Motile at 22°C, Non-motile at 37°C Yes Yersinia pestis Non-motile No Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Pages 330, 403

questions.question: Which statement is correct regarding the currently available vaccines for typhoid fever?

options.A: The Vi-CPS vaccine can be given to children under 2 years of age.
options.B: The Typhoral vaccine is given via intramuscular injection.
options.C: The Vi-rEPA vaccine can be administered to children under 2 years of age.
options.D: The Typhoral vaccine requires only a single dose for effective protection.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The Vi-rEPA vaccine can be administered to children under 2 years of age. which is the Vi antigen conjugated with recombinant Pseudomonas aeruginosa Exotoxin A, has increased immunogenicity due to the conjugation. This enhancement allows the vaccine to be effective in younger children, including those under 2 years of age. Properties of Salmonella Vaccines: Vaccine Vi-CPS Vaccine Typhoral Vaccine Parenteral TAB Vaccine Type Vi antigen capsular polysaccharide Oral live attenuated S. Typhi Ty21a Heat-killed whole cell S. Typhi/S. Paratyphi A and B Composition Purified Vi capsular polysaccharide antigen from S. Typhi strain Ty2 Stable live attenuated mutant of S. Typhi strain Ty21a Whole cell of S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi A and B, killed by heating at 50-60°C and preserved in 0.5% phenol. Dosage Single dose containing 25 µ g of Vi antigen 4 doses taken orally on days 1, 3, 5, and 7 Two doses of 0.5 ml subcutaneously at an interval of 4-6 weeks; alternatively, 0.1 ml intradermally Administration Route Intramuscular (IM) or subcutaneous Oral (enteric-coated capsules) (Option B) Subcutaneous or intradermal Age Indication Only after 2 years of age (Option A) Only after 6 years of age Recommended for troops, medical and paramedical personnel in non-endemic areas; for all children in endemic areas Booster Every 2 years Every 5 years with a full 4-dose series (Option D) Not applicable Duration of Protection 2 years 4 years 3 years Mechanism of Action Induces immune response to Vi antigen Multiplies and initiates immune response but self-destructs Induces immune response to whole bacterial cells Special Considerations Poorly immunogenic to children under 2 years No antibiotics should be given during the vaccination period Significant side effects led to discontinuation Current Status In use In use No longer in use due to side effects The Vi-CPS vaccine can be given to children under 2 years of age (Option A): The Vi-CPS (Vi capsular polysaccharide) vaccine is not recommended for children under 2 years of age due to its lower immunogenicity in younger children. The Typhoral vaccine is given via intramuscular injection (Option B): Typhoral (Ty21a), a live attenuated vaccine, is administered orally, not via injection. The Typhoral vaccine requires only a single dose for effective protection (Option D): The Typhoral (Ty21a) vaccine requires multiple doses (typically 3 or 4 doses taken on alternating days) to achieve effective immunity. Reference: Apurba S Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 308, 309 Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 305, 306

questions.question: In the context of interpreting the Widal test results for typhoid fever, which of the following statements is not accurate? diagnosis of typhoid fever. non-typhoidal Salmonella strains.

options.A: The presence of high titers of O-antibodies generally indicates a later stage of infection.
options.B: A significant rise in H-antibody titers between acute and convalescent phases can confirm a
options.C: The Widal test is most accurate when conducted within the first week of illness
options.D: False-positive results in the Widal test can occur due to prior vaccination or exposure to

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The Widal test is most accurate when conducted within the first week of illness due to the lag in antibody production. Explanation: The Widal test is generally more reliable when performed after the first week of illness. During the early stage, antibody levels may be too low to detect, making the test less reliable. The antibodies usually become detectable around the second week of illness, so testing too early can lead to false negatives. WIDAL Test: It is a highly sensitive but poorly specific serological test used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi . It detects specific antibodies in the patient's serum that react with the antigens of Salmonella typhi . The test is based on the agglutination reaction where patient serum is mixed with antigens of Salmonella typhi . If the antibodies are present, they will cause the antigens to clump together (agglutinate), indicating a positive result. The test primarily measures: O-antibodies: These are antibodies against the somatic (O) antigens of Salmonella typhi . H-antibodies: These are antibodies against the flagellar (H) antigens of Salmonella typhi . Interpretation of WIDAL Test TO TH AH BH S. Typhi + + - - S. Paratyphi A + - + - S. Paratyphi B + - - + Early infection + - - - Late infection - + - - Vaccine - + + + Where, TO : O Antigen, TH : S.Typhi H Antigen, AH : S.Paratyphi AH Antigen, BH : S. Paratyphi B H Antigen. Option A: High titers of O-antibodies are often associated with a more advanced stage of infection rather than the acute stage. In the early stages of typhoid fever, O-antibody levels may still be low. It is typically during the second or third week of illness that high O-antibody titers become detectable. Option B: A significant rise in H-antibody titers between acute and convalescent phases can confirm a diagnosis of typhoid fever. Option D: False positives can occur if the patient has been vaccinated against typhoid fever or has been exposed to non-typhoidal Salmonella strains, which can also produce cross-reacting antibodies that interfere with the test results. Reference: Apurba S Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 305

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of high fever, headache, and abdominal discomfort. He reports feeling increasingly fatigued and has developed a dry cough. On physical examination, his temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), his pulse is 60 beats/min, and he has rose-colored spots on his abdomen. Considering the timing of his symptoms, which diagnostic method is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis at this stage?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Antibody test Explanation: Blood culture is most effective during the first week of the illness but becomes less reliable as the disease progresses I . The antibody test (Widal test) is most useful in the second week when the body has had time to develop antibodies against the Salmonella Typhi antigens. Stool culture becomes more reliable in the third to fifth weeks of the illness I . Urine culture is less commonly used and less reliable compared to the other methods I . Diagnosis (mnemonic: BASU): Week 1(B) Blood culture (Option A ruled out) Week 2(A) Antibody test (WIDAL) (Option B) Week 3(S) Stool culture (Option C ruled out) Week 4(U) Urine culture (Option D ruled out) Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 302, 303

questions.question: A patient who is working as a cook in a restaurant had symptoms such as prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea 8 months ago, was diagnosed with typhoid fever and has been asymptomatic since then. Several customers who dined at the restaurant recently developed similar symptoms. The cook in this scenario is an example of a:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Temporary carrier Explanation: The term "carrier" refers to an individual who continues to shed typhoid bacilli in feces. In this case, despite being asymptomatic for 8 months, the cook is still able to transmit the pathogen (Salmonella) to others, making them a temporary carrier. Temporary carriers are individuals who carry and transmit the pathogen for a period of more than 3 months but less than a year. Convalescent carrier (Option A) refers to a person who has recovered from a disease but continues to shed the infectious agent for a period of 3 weeks to 3 months after recovery. Chronic carriers (Option C) are individuals who continue to carry and shed the pathogen for a period of more than a year. Acute carriers (Option D) are individuals who are currently infected with the pathogen and actively shedding it, typically during the acute phase of the illness when symptoms are present. Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page 302

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with a 7-day history of high-grade fever, chills, and generalized weakness. The fever has been persistent and gradually increasing in intensity, reaching 39.5°C (103.1°F) and, often rising in the afternoon and evening. The patient also reports abdominal pain and has experienced several episodes of diarrhea, characterized by intermittent loose, greenish stools which started a few days after the onset of fever. On examination, pulse is 60/min, and BP is 110/70 mmHg. He appears ill with a coated tongue and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Based on the clinical scenario above, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Typhoid Fever Explanation: Based on the provided scenario, the clinical presentation is consistent with Typhoid fever , which is typically characterized by a high-grade fever that progressively worsens over several days. Other common symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea (often with greenish stools), weakness , and hepatosplenomegaly . A coated tongue is also a characteristic sign. Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella Typhi , as well as Salmonella Paratyphi A, B, and C . Clinical features: 1. Fever Pattern Stepwise Fever : Typhoid fever is often characterized by a "stepwise" or progressively increasing fever that rises a little each day, peaking in the afternoon or evening. Sustained High Fever : As the disease progresses, the fever becomes continuous, often reaching temperatures of 39–40°C. 2. Abdominal Symptoms Abdominal Pain : Patients often experience diffuse or vague abdominal pain. Diarrhea or Constipation : Early in the illness, adults may experience constipation, while children more commonly present with diarrhea. Typhoid diarrhea is often described as “pea-soup” greenish stools. 3. Relative Bradycardia Despite high fever, patients may have a relatively lower pulse rate than expected, a phenomenon called "relative bradycardia." This is unusual in febrile illnesses and can be a clue in diagnosing typhoid. 4. Systemic Symptoms Fatigue and Weakness : Patients may feel very weak and fatigued, often feeling progressively worse over days. Headache : A common feature that can be severe, typically frontal or generalized. Myalgia : Muscle pain is common and contributes to the overall sense of malaise. 5. Gastrointestinal Findings Hepatosplenomegaly : Enlargement of the liver (hepatomegaly) and spleen (splenomegaly) can occur, typically palpable on physical examination. Coated Tongue : Patients often present with a dry, coated tongue, which may appear white or “furry.” 6. Rose Spots Rash : In some cases, patients develop rose-colored maculopapular spots on the chest or abdomen. These “rose spots” appear for a short time, lasting about 2–3 days, and are easier to see on lighter skin. 7. Mental Status Changes Confusion or Altered Consciousness : In more severe cases, especially untreated, patients may show signs of delirium or altered mental status, sometimes termed “typhoid state” in severe cases. Malaria (Option A) typically presents with high-grade fever, chills, and sweats, often in a cyclical pattern (every 48-72 hours) depending on the Plasmodium species. Appendicitis (Option C) usually presents with acute onset of abdominal pain, starting around the umbilicus and later localizing to the right lower quadrant (McBurney's point). questions.question: Given the various types of antigenic variations associated with Salmonella, which of the following statements is incorrect? 2 antigens are non-specific and widely shared among different species. can be lost after multiple subcultures. containing phenol. virulence.

options.A: Phase variation involves flagellar antigens in which Phase 1 antigens are species-specific and Phase
options.B: V-W variation refers to the presence of a surface layer of Vi antigen that masks the O antigen, which
options.C: H-0 variation is associated with the permanent loss of flagella when salmonellae are grown on agar
options.D: S-R variation is associated with a change in colony morphology and the loss of the O antigen and

questions.explanation: are grown on agar containing phenol. Correct Answer: C) H-0 variation is associated with the permanent loss of flagella when salmonellae are grown on agar-containing phenol. Explanation: H-0 variation in Salmonella is related to the loss of flagella which occurs when the bacteria are grown on agar containing phenol . It is a temporary phenotypic change and not a permanent loss ; flagella can reappear when the strain is subcultured on media without phenol. Antigenic Variation Description Mechanism H-0 Variation Loss of flagella Phenotypic and temporary change when grown on agar containing phenol. Phase Variation Alternation between two sets of flagellar antigens (Phase 1 and Phase 2) Involves two sets of genes in the bacterial genome. Phase 1 antigens are species-specific or shared by a few species, while Phase 2 antigens are more widely shared. (Option A) V-W Variation Presence of Vi antigen (V form) and loss of Vi antigen (W form) Fresh isolates carry Vi antigen masking the O antigen (V form). Vi antigen is lost after several subcultures, exposing the O antigen (W form). (Option B) S-R Variation Change from smooth (S) to rough (R) colonies Loss of O antigen and virulence, often through mutation. (Option D) Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page 299, 300

options.A: Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine is a formalin-killed vaccine administered
options.B: Chemoprophylaxis of Yersinia involves administration of Cotrimoxazole or Tetracycline orally for at
options.C: Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine provides protection against all clinical types of plague.
options.D: The killed vaccine provides protection for up to 6 months.

questions.explanation: clinical types of plague. Correct Answer: C) Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine provides protection against all clinical types of plague. Explanation: Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine is a formalin-killed vaccine administered subcutaneously, and it provides protection specifically against bubonic plague for up to 6 months. It does not provide protection against other subtypes of plague, such as pneumonic or septicemic plague. Prophylaxis against Yersinia pestis Vaccine Notes Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine Formalin-killed vaccine, administered subcutaneously. Protects against bubonic plague. Provides protection for up to 6 months. (Option A and D) Live vaccine No longer recommended Chemoprophylaxis Cotrimoxazole/Tetracycline for 5 days (Option B) Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 330

questions.question: Match the following Klebsiella species with the diseases they commonly cause: 1. Klebsiella pneumoniae A. Granuloma inguinale 2. Klebsiella oxytoca B. Pneumonia 3. Klebsiella granulomatis C. Rhinoscleroma 4. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis D. Hemorrhagic colitis
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C Explanation: Klebsiella species: They are usually found as commensals in human intestines and as saprophytes in soil. It has three species—K. pneumoniae, K. oxytoca and K. granulomatis. K. pneumoniae further comprises three subspecies. The diseases caused by them can be summarized as follows: Klebsiella Species Disease Caused Symptoms Klebsiella pneumoniae Pneumonia Productive cough with "currant jelly" sputum, fever, chills, chest pain, difficulty breathing Klebsiella oxytoca Hemorrhagic colitis Bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and cramping, nausea, vomiting Klebsiella granulomatis Granuloma inguinale Painless, beefy-red genital or anal ulcers, tissue granulation, bleeding from lesions Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis Rhinoscleroma Nasal congestion, nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, crusting, swelling, tissue thickening, deformity

questions.question: In a microbiological study, two different strains of Proteus are inoculated at separate points on the same agar plate containing a non-inhibitory medium. Upon observation, the areas of growth from each strain remain distinctly separate with a line of demarcation between them. What phenomenon is being demonstrated in this experiment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Dienes phenomenon Explanation: Dienes phenomenon helps in identifying strains of Proteus in different patients. Two strains of Proteus bacteria inoculate at separate points on the agar plate and their interaction is noted. If the two strains of Proteus are identical or closely related, their growth patterns will exhibit a tendency to merge or coalesce. If the two strains are different or genetically distinct, their growth patterns will remain separate and distinctive line of demarcation seen on the agar plate. Biofilm formation (Option A): Biofilms refers to the ability of bacteria to adhere to surfaces and form slimy layers for survival. Quellung reaction (Option B) Quellung reaction: This test involves the swelling of the bacterial capsule in the presence of specific antisera and is used to identify encapsulated bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae. Kirby-Bauer test (Option D) Kirby-Bauer test is used to determine the antibiotic susceptibility of bacteria. Antibiotic discs are placed on an agar plate inoculated with bacteria, and the zone of inhibition around each disc indicates whether the bacteria are susceptible, intermediate, or resistant to the antibiotic.

questions.question: Which of the following bacteria exhibits a characteristic pattern as shown below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: The image above indicates swarming motility . Swarming motility is the ability of certain bacteria to move rapidly over a semi-solid surface, resulting in a characteristic concentric growth pattern. Swarming can be avoided by Increasing agar concentration ( 5-6% agar) : makes it harder for motile bacteria to spread across the surface, thus reducing swarming . Normal agar concentration is 2% Chemicals : like Chloral hydrate, sodium azide, alcohol, sulphonamides, surface-active agents, or boric acid inhibit bacterial swarming MacConkey agar : this contains bile salts like taurocholate, which are known to inhibit swarming. Most common bacteria showing swarming motility: Proteus: When Proteus bacteria are grown on blood agar, they produce a uniform film of growth that can cover the entire plate or appear as concentric circles around the point of inoculation Clostridium tetani: C. tetani in cooked meat broth exhibits characteristic swarming growth on blood agar plates containing polymyxin B when incubated anaerobically. Vibrio parahaemolyticus: Swarming motility, is effectively mediated by the lateral flagellar (laf) system in Vibrio parahaemolyticus Other organisms that cause swarming motility are: Vibrio Alginolyticus Bacillus Cereus Serratia Salmonella

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false?

options.A: All members of Tribe Proteeae test positive for the phenylalanine deaminase (PPA) test
options.B: Morganella tests positive for Urease test
options.C: Proteus lowers urine pH and contributes to the formation of bladder stones.
options.D: Providencia tests negative for Urease test

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Proteus lowers urine pH and contributes to the formation of bladder stones raises urine pH . This can contribute to the formation of bladder stones. Tribe Proteeae classification: All members of Tribe Proteeae test positive for the phenylalanine deaminase (PPA) test (Option A) Members of the Tribe Proteeae, which includes Proteus , Morganella , and Providencia , are positive for the phenylalanine deaminase test. This test differentiates them from other Enterobacteriaceae. Morganella tests positive for the Urease test (Option B): This statement is true. Morganella species are urease-positive, meaning they produce urease, which hydrolyzes urea to ammonia and increases the pH. Providencia tests negative for the Urease test (Option D): Providencia species generally test negative for urease, differentiating them from Proteus and Morganella in the Proteeae tribe. Reference: Apurba S Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd edition, Pages 76, 749, 750

questions.question: A 35-year-old male patient, hospitalized for two weeks following a motor vehicle accident, presents with fever, chills, and difficulty breathing. He has a central venous catheter in place. Blood cultures grow a gram-negative, facultative anaerobic bacillus that produces a red pigment on nutrient agar. Which of the following is NOT a feature of this organism?

options.A: Organisms commonly found in healthcare facilities
options.B: Respiratory infection characterized by bloody sputum
options.C: Cause keratitis in contact lens wearers
options.D: Prodigiosin is a red pigment seen in culture

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Respiratory infection characterized by bloody sputum Explanation: The organism responsible for the patient's symptoms and the growth of a gram-negative, facultative anaerobic bacillus that produces a red pigment on nutrient agar is Serratia marcescens. It is responsible for the phenomenon known as "pseudohemoptysis " where sputum samples turn red, mimicking the appearance of blood in the sputum. Serratia marcescens emerged as a significant cause of infections in healthcare settings , particularly among patients with compromised immune systems. (Option A) Causes: Pneumonia (Pseudohemoptysis- Red color sputum) Contact lens keratitis (Option C) Meningitis, Cardiovascular problems, Septicemia in immunocompromised Culture: Presents as a non-diffusible red pigment at room temperature. Prodigiosin is responsible for Pseudohemoptysis (red pigmented sputum) (Option D) Reference: Apurba S Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd edition, Pages 76, 615, 616 Serratia marcescens Keratitis: Clinical Features, Risk Factors, Treatment, and Outcomes | IOVS .

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with a urinary tract infection. A urine sample is cultured on MacConkey agar. The colonies appear pink and mucoid. A string test is performed, and the colonies form a viscous string longer than 5 mm. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Klebsiella pneumoniae Explanation: The combination of pink, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar and a positive string test strongly suggests that the causative organism is Klebsiella pneumoniae. The described characteristics of the bacterial culture help distinguish between different organisms: MacConkey Agar : This is a selective and differential medium that indicates lactose fermentation. Both Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae ferment lactose, producing pink colonies. Mucoid Colonies : Klebsiella pneumoniae is known for producing mucoid colonies due to its polysaccharide capsule, which is more prominent than that of Escherichia coli. String Test : The string test involves touching a colony with an inoculating loop and pulling it away slowly. If a string longer than 5 mm forms, it indicates a hyperviscous strain, which is characteristic of Klebsiella pneumoniae. Laboratory diagnosis of Klebsiella pneumoniae: Gram staining : It is short, plump, straight capsulated gram-negative rods Culture: On MacConkey agar, it produces large dome-shaped mucoid (due to capsule) sticky, pink color, lactose fermenting colonies Identification: Identification of K. pneumoniae from colonies is made either by automated identification systems such as MALDI-TOF or VITEK; or by conventional biochemical tests as described below It is catalase positive and oxidase negative ICUT tests: Indole test (negative), citrate test (positive), urease test (positive) and TSI (triple sugar iron agar) test shows acid/acid, gas present, H2S absent. Thus, the combination of pink, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar and a positive string test strongly suggests that the causative organism is Klebsiella pneumoniae. Escherichia coli (Option A) : While it also ferments lactose and may appear pink on MacConkey agar, it does not typically have a mucoid appearance or give a positive string test. Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C) : Non-lactose fermenting, typically appears colorless on MacConkey agar and does not have a mucoid appearance. Proteus mirabilis (Option D) : Non-lactose fermenting and does not appear mucoid. It typically exhibits swarming motility on non-selective media and does not give a positive string test.

questions.question: Which of the following infections is not typically caused by the recent- hyperviscous, hypervirulent strain of Klebsiella pneumoniae?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Gastroenteritis Explanation: The recent strain of Klebsiella pneumoniae is known to cause community-acquired pneumonia, meningitis and sepsis. Hence gastroenteritis is the correct answer. Hyper-viscous, hyper-virulent strain of Klebsiella pneumoniae: Hyperviscous, hypervirulent Resistant to treatment Clinical manifestations: II Community-acquired pneumonia : Often accompanied by lung abscesses and necrotizing infection. This type of pneumonia can rapidly progress, leading to complications like empyema or sepsis. (Option A) Meningitis : Although less common than pneumonia or sepsis, hvKp can invade the central nervous system, leading to meningitis. Typical K. pneumoniae strains do not frequently cause meningitis, especially in otherwise healthy individuals. (Option B) Sepsis : Hypervirulent K. pneumoniae is frequently implicated in cases of bacteremia and sepsis. This strain can spread through the bloodstream, leading to a widespread systemic infection that can cause multiorgan failure, even in immunocompetent patients. (Option D) Gastroenteritis : While K. pneumoniae may occasionally be isolated in cases of gastroenteritis, this is generally not due to the hypervirulent strain and is not a common infection associated with hvKp. Gastrointestinal infections are typically linked to pathogens like Escherichia coli , Salmonella , and Shigella , rather than Klebsiella species.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with painless, progressive genital ulcers. A tissue biopsy is taken, and a Wright-Giemsa stain is performed. The microscopic examination reveals Donovan bodies within macrophages as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Granuloma inguinale Explanation: The clinical presentation of painless, progressive genital ulcers, along with the presence of c on Wright-Giemsa stain, is characteristic of granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Donovan bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in macrophages and are a diagnostic feature of this condition. Syphilis (Option A): Typically presents with painless genital ulcers but is diagnosed by serologic tests and darkfield microscopy, not by finding Donovan bodies. Gonorrhea (Option B): Generally presents with purulent discharge and painful urination; it does not produce Donovan bodies. Chlamydia (Option C): Often asymptomatic or presents with discharge and dysuria, but also does not produce Donovan bodies.
